title: 109_hr1942
content: The "527 Transparency Act of 2005" requires reporting frequency to increase to quarterly in non-election years. The reporting frequency in non-election years is increased to quarterly, with reports due by the fifteenth day after the end of each calendar quarter. The amendment applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2005. SEC. 4956 imposes a tax on political organizations failing to meet disclosure requirements. SEC. 4956 imposes a 30 percent tax on political organizations for failing to disclose contributions or expenditures, with organization managers being jointly and severally liable for the tax. SEC. 4956 defines an organization manager as an officer, director, or trustee of a political organization. The term "political organization" is defined by section 527(e)(1). Conforming amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code regarding political organizations failing to meet reporting requirements. Sec. 4956 imposes a tax on political organizations failing to meet disclosure requirements. The effective date for these amendments is for taxable years starting after December 31, 2005. Additionally, there is a denial of the gift tax exclusion for transfers to political organizations under section 2501(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The text discusses exceptions to the transfer of money or property to political organizations for their use, specifically regarding disclosure requirements. It also mentions a notice to contributors regarding denial of gift tax exception for failure to disclose. The Secretary requires organizations to notify contributors of any failure to disclose within 90 days of determination. The exception under section 2501(a)(4)(A) does not apply to contributions in the same calendar year. Effective date for amendments is after December 31, 2005.
